title: Open Data in Practice: Open data innovation
displayTitle: Open Data in Practice: Open data innovation
body: Having covered the practical side of publishing data, this course now turns its focus to innovation. How do businesses innovate using open data? Can you make money from open data? And what does a value proposition based on open data look like? By the end of this course, participants will have discovered the answers to these questions, formed their own business models and practiced their pitch.
instruction: The sessions of the course are briefly described below.

_items.title: Open data value propositions
_items.body:
This session explores the concepts of innovation and value propositions for open data.

We explore when companies need to innovate and the key techniques involved. We also look at existing examples of companies that did and did not innovate.

_items.title: Creating a business model
_items.body:
This session takes a practical approach to creating a value proposition and business model around open data.

We explore the business model canvas and look at how you can create a balanced business from open data.

_items.title: Perfect pitching
_items.body:
The final session challenges participants to pitch a new innovation with open data.

Communicating the impact of open data is of critical importance; this session offers participants practical experience in how to clearly communicate impact and innovation to others.

title: Building the value proposition
body: Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Unlike a traditional business where your resources belong only to you and can be protected, open data can be used by others at the same time. To understand how businesses that use open data operate, we need to consider the value proposition of open data to a business.
instruction: Click below to explore tools that unlock data that is on the Web

_items.title: What is a value proposition?
_items.body: A value proposition is a credible justification for why your customers will interact with your business in the ways you expect. The core of a value proposition is the problem(s) you solve for your customers. By identifying a problem your customers have and creating a solution to that problem, you create a justification for them to interact with your business.

_items.title: Why are value propositions important?
_items.body: The value proposition of a business is the core of its business model. Without a strong value proposition, a business does not have the justification for operating. The value proposition is also the logic on which the rest of the business is based. If, for example, a business solves a problem for its customers and helps them save money or time, there is a reason to charge for this service. If, however, the problem the business solves is a problem that customers do not value in monetary terms, that business may need to seek alternative sources of revenue. Understanding the value proposition allows the business to anchor decisions in how customers will interact.

_items.title: The value proposition of open
_items.body: Businesses working in 'open' – whether open source software or open data – need to consider the value proposition of the open resources they consume. This consideration is important when developing a value proposition because using someone else's data or software in your business changes the problem you solve.

_items.alt: Creating a value proposition for an open data business
_items.title: Creating a value proposition for an open data business
_items.body: Creating the value proposition for an open data business is different from a traditional business. Where a closed business solves a problem with a solution the customer cannot get anywhere else, an open business uses solutions that are already available in some form elsewhere. This means that the value proposition for an open business is usually based on being more convenient or cost-effective than the alternatives. Writing a strong value proposition for an open data business means explaining what problem you solve for a customer and why your solution is better than going directly to the data themselves.

title: Business value: case studies
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out moreSelect the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: ScholarDream
_items.body:
Scholardreamallows parents to find schools for their children and also helps schools run some of their operations in the cloud.

Scholardream brings together performance statistics on schools with availability. The service solves the problem of spending hours hunting for and comparing availble schooling.

_items.title: Batainfo
_items.body:
BataInfo is an application that provides data on films, restaurants, sports, fashion and more. Batainfo consumes data from a variety of differenrt sources and gives users details like when and where an event is happening, and what it's about.

Batainfo solves the problem for customers of having to go to many different websites to discover entertainment options. By making it simple for customers to get everything in one app, Batainfo saves time and also offers entertainment providers an attractive channel to customers.

_items.title: Agrimark
_items.body: Agrimark connects farmers with the market for their crops. For farmers in Tanzania, often located in rural areas, finding suppliers for crops can be a difficult process. Likewise for hotels, restaurants and other businesses, finding food at the best price is challenging. Agrimark solves both challenges by creating an open marketplace for buyers and sellers of produce.

title: The business model canvas
body:
The business model canvas offers a logical view of any company. It is key to identifying any areas of weakness or potential opportunity.

The canvas is formed of nine key boxes, which are divided into three key areas with the value proposition in the middle.

To the left of the value proposition are your activities and partnerships that create that value. On the right are your customers and channels to your customers. Finally, underpinning the whole model are costs and revenue.

The perfect business model canvas should be balanced left to right with a strong foundation in the financial underpinning; it should not be one-side heavy.

title: Creating a canvas
body:
There are a number of key pointers that can help you to create a business model canvas

1. Stick to the value proposition

Do not expand the scope of your idea in order to fill in any part of the canvas. If you can't fill a box in with your value proposition, ask yourself whether the value proposition is right

2. Less is more

A maximum of three points in each box is best. Do you want your business to be managing more that 24 different aspects?

3. Pigs don't fly

While innovation is encouraged, creating new categories of customers who will never exist won't help you. The same applies to partners and revenue. Be realistic in all areas of the canvas.

title: The eight-box canvas
body: Having filled in your value proposition, in the middle of the canvas, there are eight other boxes to complete.

_items.title: Key partners
_items.body: Partners supply you and help you optimise your work. In an open data business, who are your sources of data? Who is supplying the most important services to you? Your key partners need to have a close working relationship with you to offer high levels of service guarantee.

_items.title: Key activities
_items.body: What are your key activities that support the business? How much time will you need to support partners, customers, development, marketing and sales of the product?

_items.title: Key resources
_items.body: Who and what do you need in order to deliver your key activities and value proposition? Do you need to register rights over your products and hold IP? What is the thing that customers are buying?

_items.title: Cost structure
_items.body: What fixed and variable costs will you have? How much will resources and activities cost?

_items.title: Customer segments
_items.body: For who are you creating value? Does this segment exist? Can you personally name anyone in each segment? Would they buy your product at the price you are proposing?

_items.title: Customer relationships
_items.body: What type of relationship will you have with each customer segment? How costly are they? How do you keep them coming back to your product?

_items.title: Channels
_items.body: How will you reach and engage with your customer segments? How do you market, drive purchase, deliver, evaluate and provide care?

_items.title: Revenue streams
_items.body: How do you make money? What is the cost of the value you are creating? Do your revenue streams relate to channels and relationships?

title: The elevator pitch
body: The idea for the elevator pitch comes from the theory that if you were to get in the lift of a skyscraper in New York, and the CEO of your company is in the lift with you, then you have approximately 90 seconds between the lift doors closing and opening again on the very top floor to pitch an idea to them and potentially change your life forever.

title: Creating a pitch
body: There are two key parts to an elevator pitch: the pain statement and the value proposition.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out moreSelect the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more

_items.title: The pain statement
_items.body:
Doesn't it frustrate you when...

The pain statement should be short and succinct, and be designed to instantly catch the attention of your audience. If they are not leaning forward in their chair (metaphorically) by the end of your pain statement, it didn't work.

_items.title: The value proposition
_items.body:
Well, I've got a great solution!

This is basically the value proposition from your business model canvas and should be the hook that reels in your catch (the CEO).

title: Pitching tips
body: To help you with your pitching, follow the simple guidelines below:

_items.title: Be succinct
_items.body:
Keep sentences short. Pause between topics. Focus on the one thing you want remembered.

The Hemminway App can even help score your phrasing

_items.title: Maintain audience attention
_items.body: Maintain eye contact. Use an open posture. Think about what you would want to hear if it was you being pitched to.

_items.title: Don't use jargon
_items.body: Avoid acronyms wherever you can. Focus on the problem, not the technology that solves it.

_items.alt: Don't ask questions, fosuc on opportunities
_items.title: Don't ask questions, focus on opportunities
_items.body:
Every solution is likely to have some problematic issues. Don't ask open questions about these issues.

A good trick during a pitch is to leave out one clear business opportunity. If the person you are pitching to then says 'We could also do ...' (mentioning that idea), then say 'Great idea, we should work on that'. This gives them ownership and involvement in the product. This is the hook and line method, you cast your hook and see if they bite.

_items.title: Use lists of three
_items.body:
From a ninety-second pitch you are not going to remember much, so work with a list of three.

Even better if the list of three focuses on the three areas of the business model canvas, eg

This solution:

  1. solves the customers problem...
  2. makes better use of partner relationships...
  3. increases margin...

_items.title: Repeat key points
_items.body: Repeat your list of three. Each point should be succinct, and contain only words the audience understands.

_items.title: Make an emotional connection
_items.body: If you can make both a personal and professional connection, this might help with engagement. Charity campaign videos are good examples of how to make an emotional connection that helps people part with their money.

title: Music to the ears
body:
Q: Why was Steve Jobs so good at pitching?

A: Because the pitches had similar structures to popular music

The most famous example of this is the original launch keynote for the iPhone back in 2007:

  • Intro (8 words)
  • Verse 1 (10-7-9 words per sentence)
  • Verse 2 (10-7-9)
  • Chorus (3-2-3)
  • Chorus (3-2-3)
  • Middle 8 (6-4-5)
  • Ending (1-8-4)

A very clever way of making an emotional connection and appealing to our own fondness for music.
